docs.snippet: The Richmond correspondent of the Columbia South Carolinian relates the following  "On the retreat, a tired Yankee stooped at a farm-house and begged for water. Mrs. THORNTON, the owner, handed him a tumbler, pouring a little brandy into it, as he...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Richmond correspondent of the Columbia South Carolinian relates the following "On the retreat, a tired Yankee stooped at a farm-house and begged for water. Mrs. THORNTON, the owner, handed him a tumbler, pouring a little brandy into it, as he seemed very exhausted. As she offered it, he shrank back for a moment, but took it and drank it.

docs.snippet: The pressure of the times will, hardly interfere with the health and pleasure of City folk, by driving them from the narrow quarters, late hours and elaborate dinners of the fashionable resorts, to the country inns and farm-houses, the hunting and...
docs.lead_paragraph: The pressure of the times will, hardly interfere with the health and pleasure of City folk, by driving them from the narrow quarters, late hours and elaborate dinners of the fashionable resorts, to the country inns and farm-houses, the hunting and fishing, and the riding and clambering of the fresh mountain districts, so easily accessible on the west and the north.

docs.snippet: SANDY HOOK, Monday, Aug. 12. On Saturday night Sergeant TOMPKINS, of Com  pany A, Second Cavalry, was sent out in charge of the pickets, and it was observed that he took with him his entire equipments.
docs.lead_paragraph: SANDY HOOK, Monday, Aug. 12. On Saturday night Sergeant TOMPKINS, of Com pany A, Second Cavalry, was sent out in charge of the pickets, and it was observed that he took with him his entire equipments.

docs.snippet: We are glad to learn that letters have been re  ceived in the city this morning, bringing the intelligence of the safety of several of the members of the Fifth Massachusetts who have before been reported missing. The letters say that they were...
docs.lead_paragraph: We are glad to learn that letters have been re ceived in the city this morning, bringing the intelligence of the safety of several of the members of the Fifth Massachusetts who have before been reported missing. The letters say that they were captured and taken to Richmond, and that they are well,and are well treated.

docs.snippet: PANAMA, Saturday, Aug. 3, 1861. The mails from Central and South America,  and from Bogota, not being due till to-morrow, I have but little to write to-day.

headline.main: NEW-GRANADA.; Conflicting Reports from Bogota--How the Non-Recognition of the Blockade is Received--Venezuela in a State of Auarchy,etc.

docs.lead_paragraph: PANAMA, Saturday, Aug. 3, 1861. The mails from Central and South America, and from Bogota, not being due till to-morrow, I have but little to write to-day.

headline.main: NOTES OF THE REBELLION.; CONGRESSMEN ON THE BATTLE-FIELD. THE OPINION OF SENATOR LANE.

docs.lead_paragraph: EXPERIENCES OF HON. A.G. RIDDLE, OF OHIO. An article in the Cleveland (Ohio) Herald se verely critising the course which Hon. A.G. RIDDLE, of Ohio, was represented to have taken at the battle of Bull Run, has elicited a reply from that gentlemen which appears in the Cleveland Leader. He says: "To those who find in the fact that I was at the battle at all, grave cause of censure, I can only...

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: CIVIL WAR (THE WAR BETWEEN THE STATES)

docs.snippet: On Saturday night, June 22, a deserter from the rebel army, quartered in the City of New-Orleans, succeeded in safety reaching the United States steam sloop Brooklyn, of the blockading squadron, now stationed at Pass-a-l'Outre.

headline.main: THE BLOCKADING SERVICE.; LETTER FROM ON BOARD THE BROOKLYN. A DESERTER FROM NEW-ORLEANS INTERESTING INFORMATION CONDITION OF THE CITY PLANS FOR DESTROYING THE BROOKLYN, ETC. PROBABLE INTENTION TO RUN THE BLOCKADE.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, June 22, a deserter from the rebel army, quartered in the City of New-Orleans, succeeded in safety reaching the United States steam sloop Brooklyn, of the blockading squadron, now stationed at Pass-a-l'Outre.

docs.snippet: The arrival of a portion of the New-York Light Artillery troop, known as the "Ira Harris Guard," is most opportune. It is a move in the right direction that has long been needed.

headline.main: NOTES OF THE REBELLION; FROM FORTRESS MONROE. MOVEMENTS IN ARIZONA. HOW IT WAS DONE THE CHEROKEES. A FEMALE SPY. THE REBEL WAR VESSELS. A JOHN BROWN MAN.

docs.lead_paragraph: The arrival of a portion of the New-York Light Artillery troop, known as the "Ira Harris Guard," is most opportune. It is a move in the right direction that has long been needed.
